attributes.title: Understanding changes in people’s opinions about chronic health conditions in the UK
attributes.description:
This study is a follow-up of project ref osf.io/y6f3q that was designed to: (a) understand UK public perceptions of population prevalence and personal risk of cancer and heart disease (b) extend current US research by (i) examining public perceptions and personal risk in relation to other diseases such as hearing loss. (ii) exploring whether perceived severity influences UK public perceptions of population prevalence and personal risk. 

We are re-contacting a randomly selected subsample (N = 6000) on the original 10,401 respondents in order to examine: (a) changes in UK public perceptions of population prevalence and personal risk of hearing loss, cancer and heart disease; (b) UK public perceptions of population prevalence and personal risk of diabetes and arthritis; and (c) whether measures of people's capabilities, opportunities and motivations are predictive of having participated in hearing screening one year later.

q2.value:
Part 1 of the study is to replicate Scheideler et al. (2017, JBM) in the UK and show that public perceptions of cancer risk exceed those of heart disease risk, but additionally to show that: (a) hearing health risk is underestimated compared to either cancer or heart disease, and (b) perceived severity of hearing loss is lower than either cancer or heart disease.  We anticipate that further findings will be consistent with Scheideler et al. (2017, JBM), but that the risks of hearing health will consistently be regarded as lower than cancer or heart disease.  We additionally ask about perceptions of diabetes and arthritis and anticipate a similar pattern of findings, namely, that cancer and heart disease will be perceived to be riskier and more severe than arthritis and diabetes.  We further anticipate that arthritis and diabetes will be perceived to be riskier and more severe than hearing health. 

Part 2 of the study will explore changes in public perceptions.  Due to the advent of the COVID-19 pandemic, we anticipate that, although the relative risks/perceived severities of cancer, heart disease and hearing loss will remain, the absolute risks/perceived severities will be lower. 

Part 3 of the study is to examine whether a new COM-B measure is predictive of having attended hearing screening in the last year.  We predict that perceptions of capabilities, opportunities and motivations will be significant predictors of attendance at hearing screening in the preceding 12 months.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: For the purpose of comparing reactions to diabetes and arthritis with perceptions of cancer, heart disease and hearing loss, the study is cross-sectional.  For the purpose  of analysing changes over time and the predictive validity of the COM-B model, the design is longitudinal.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Yougov will collect questionnaire data from a representative sample of 6,000 UK adults

q11.value: A random sample of the original 10,401 respondents (N = 6,000) will be approached and it is estimated that 70-80% will respond.

question.value: Please see attached file.

The cross-sectional analyses will mostly be descriptive, but inferential statistics will be similar to Scheideler et al (2017, JBM).  The longitudinal analyses of change over time will be conducted using repeated measures MANOVA, with scrutiny of univariate ANOVAs to see where differences lie.  The longitudinal analysis of the predictive validity of the COM-B questionnaire will include zero-order correlations and multiple regression.

q1.value: Efficacy of Treatments to Improve Vulvar, introit or vestibule atrophy: A Systematic Review.

q3.value: Vulvar atrophy is a common condition generally associated with vaginal and urinary atrophy although rarely separated from them. Symptoms include irritation, itching, soreness, burning, and dyspareunia, and has a substantial effect on quality of life. There are numerous treatments for vaginal atrophy but there is little medical literature on the effectiveness of treatments for vulvar atrophy and its consequences. Our objective is to analyzed the efficacy of treatments for improving the vulvar, introit or vestibular atrophy in postmenopausal women?

q4.value: Not any treatment for vaginal atrophy improve vulvar, introit or vestibular atrophy

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: In order to identify eligible articles, we will perform a systematic review of the literature.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
In order to identify eligible articles, we will perform a systematic review of the literature. The  following databases will be searched: MEDLINE (via PubMed), The Cochrane Library (CENTRAL),  and SCOPUS, from their inception until the most recent date. 
We  will  design  a  search  strategy,  tailored  to  the  requirements  of  each  database,  which  will include  a  combination  of  controlled  vocabulary  and search  terms  related  to  each  clinical  question and the associated inclusion criteria. When necessary, validated filters will be also used to retrieve the appropriate designs. 
Additional studies will be identified by hand searching of reference lists of relevant studies or reviews identified. Initially, no restrictions will be applied in terms of language, date or status of publication. We will report the process of study se lection in a PRISMA flowchart.
	
Types of study to be included 
It is expected to find various types of study designs, providing data on the outcomes of interest for the review. We will consider other systematic reviews addressing the clinical questions and providing relevant data for our review. In addition, we will include both randomized controlled trials (RCTs), extension studies and follow up reports of trials and sound observational studies, which have not been included in previous reviews or those providing compelling data for the purposes of our reviews. 
We will consider those observational studies with a minimum quality of the analyzed data (large clinical registers or administrative data, nationwide cohorts, prospective follow up studies, or large case control studies).

Participants/population 
Postmenopausal women  of  any  age,  with  any  of  the  conditions  of  interest  to  the  review and receiving (or candidates to receive) local o systemic therapy for vulvar atrophy. 

Intervention(s), exposure(s) 
Any type of treatments (drugs or physical treatments) with different formulations and routes of administration.
	
Comparator(s)/control 
Placebo or no treatment; different treatment durations; any drugs compared to each other. 

Context 
Any context; however, it is reasonable to consider that treatment will be administered mostly on ambulatory (community) basis. 

Primary outcome(s) 
Efficacy and security of each treatment
if the condition allows we will do meta-analysis

attributes.title: Replication study of Abortion
attributes.description: In this replication, we aim to replicate the findings of Pacilli et al.,'s studies about how elective abortion affected moral outrage and humanness in China.

item1.value: The decision to abort would increase people’s moral outrage toward the decision makers. The decision to abort would reduce the humanness of both woman and man through the mediation of elicited moral outrage.

item2.value: Abortion is quite controversial in China. People easily have a stigma to women who aborted. To explore how elective abortion affects people’s moral emotion and dehumanization to women and men is helpful to reduce the stigma. Practically, it will be beneficial for women to obtain safe abortion and protect and improve their reproductive rights.

item3.value: In a 2 (Woman’s Decision to Abort: abort vs. Not abort) × 2 (Lexical Marker: fetus vs. child) factorial design , Study 1 revealed a significant main effect of decision emerged for moral outrage, ηp2 = .40, HN ,ηp2 =.36, and HU, ηp2 =.08 .Then the study added a new within-participant variable (traditional vs. nontraditional female professions) , while the decision to abort and the lexical marker as between-participant variables, finding that a significant main effect of the type of professions emerged, ηp2 = .24, as well as a significant interaction between the decision and the type of profession , ηp2 = .23 . In a 2 (Target: judgment of the woman vs. judgment of the man) × 2 (Type of Decision: abort vs. not-abort) ×3 (Responsibility of the Choice: responsibility of the woman vs. responsibility of the man vs. responsibility of the couple) mixed factorial design, Study 2 found significant three-way interactions for moral outrage, ηp2 = .38, HN, ηp2 = .46, and HU, ηp2 = .38. Study 2 also revealed a significant three-way interaction between the type of decision, the responsibility of the decision, and the type of profession, ηp2 = .21.

item4.value: In the ANOVA on depend variables, the confidence intervals of the original effects were not reported.

item5.value: In Study 1, 110 participants completed the survey. In Study 2, 265 participants were included in the analysis.

item9.value: It should be on computers or other electronic devices, such as mobile phones.

item11.value: We obtained the materials of the two studies by requesting the original first author, and we used them to conduct direct replications.

item15.value: In study 1, the target sample size is 300, and in study 2, it is 400

item16.value: We use G*power to calculate the required sample size. According to the smallest effect size in the original study 1 (ηp2 = .08) in the original study, the effect size of f should be 0.29. To detect such a medium effect with power= .95, the sample size is 202.  The effect sizes in the original study 2 are very large, and the required sample size is less than 100 when using one of the effect sizes to calculate it. Therefore, we used the medium effect size (f =.25) to calculate the required sample size. G*Power indicated that 323 participants were sufficient to obtain 95% power. Because we will distribute the study online by the platform of Qualtrics, and participants may will choose to voluntarily complete the survey, we cannot assure that every participant who clicks the web link of the survey will complete the whole survey. Therefore, we will recruit about 300 participants in study 1 and 400 participants in study 2 to ensure there will be enough valid data.

item24.value:
One difference between the original studies and ours is on remuneration. In the original studies, participants were given course credits for participation. In our studies, participants will complete the surveys voluntarily. We will remunerate participants, if we can not recruit enough participants who voluntarily take part in.
As we conduct the replication studies in China, the participants populations will be Chinese people. Such a difference is the focus of our replications. Similar to the original studies, we will also recruit undergraduate students.

item25.value: Regarding the differences on remuneration, what we worry is that voluntary participants may answer questions carelessly. We think that the completing time of participants can reflect their carefulness. Participants spend either short or long time completing the survey usually implies that they do not answer questions carefully. Therefore, we will exclude participants whose completing time is beyond ±3 standard deviations. In addition, there is a question to check whether participants has read the experimental manipulation carefully.

item26.value: According to a manipulation question, participants who do not correctly remember whether the woman in the vignette had decided to abort or not in both studies and male participants in study 1 will be removed. In addition, as an online test, participants, who click the web link but do not complete the measure of the survey and whose completing time is beyond ±3 standard deviations, will be removed.

item27.value: The analysis will be the same to the original study.

item28.value: As employing a sufficiently similar methodology to the original study, and as clarifying any differences from the original study. In addition, the investigator is independent from the original researcher.

attributes.title: A cross-cultural study of misrepresenting contributions in a public goods game
attributes.description: Individuals may have direct strategic and more general reputation-related reasons for misrepresenting their contributions to common cooperative projects. We investigate the effects of being able to misrepresent contributions in a public goods game, in a large interactive online decision making experiment conducted in two different cultures (China and USA). By implementing different experimental treatments, we aim to test our expectation that the possibility for misrepresenting undermines cooperation and whether this effect is even stronger if it is possible to build a personal reputation. For these hypotheses, the subject pools in China and the USA should be considered as independent replications. In addition, we will test our expectation that reputation concerns are relatively stronger in China, so that the possibility for misrepresentation disproportionally undermines cooperation when reputation concerns are relevant.

q1.value: A cross-cultural study of misrepresenting contributions in a public goods game

q2.value: Pieter van den Berg, Siyuan Liu, Tom Wenseleers, Zhang, Jianlei

q3.value: Individuals may have direct strategic and more general reputation-related reasons for misrepresenting their contributions to common cooperative projects. We investigate the effects of being able to misrepresent contributions in a public goods game, in a large interactive online decision making experiment conducted in two different cultures (China and USA). By implementing different experimental treatments, we aim to test our expectation that the possibility for misrepresenting undermines cooperation and whether this effect is even stronger if it is possible to build a personal reputation. For these hypotheses, the subject pools in China and the USA should be considered as independent replications. In addition, we will test our expectation that reputation concerns are relatively stronger in China, so that the possibility for misrepresentation disproportionally undermines cooperation when reputation concerns are relevant.

q4.value:
We have a number of expectations about the results of the experiment within both cultures:
1.	We expect that the degree of misrepresentation undermines cooperation. Specific predictions: 
a.	There will be less cooperation in the treatments in which misrepresentation is possible
b.	There will be less cooperation if there was more misrepresentation in the previous round
c.	There will be more misrepresentation if there was more misrepresentation in the previous round

2.	We expect that individuals are motivated to misrepresent both by direct strategic concerns (to elicit future cooperation from interaction partners) and by more general reputational concerns (to be seen as a generally cooperative person). We designed our experiment in such a way that we can tease the effects of these two motivations apart. We have two treatments in which misrepresentation is possible and two in which it is not possible. For both these pairs of treatments, in one of them only the total stated contributions of all interaction partners are relayed the group members after decisions are made, so reputation concerns are less important. In the other, individual stated contributions are fed back to the interaction partners, leading to a higher importance of reputation concerns. Specific predictions: 
a.	we expect more cooperation in the treatment where individual stated contributions are specifically mentioned and where misrepresentation is not possible, than in the treatment without misrepresentation that only mentions total contributions.
b.	We expect more misrepresentation in the treatment where individual stated contributions are mentioned than where they are not, but lower cooperation (so when misrepresentation is possible, we expect the opposite effect of reputation as under a)
c.	We expect an interaction between the possibility of misrepresentation and the showing of individual contributions, in such a way that the differences in cooperation rates between the experimental treatments are as follows:
i.	Highest cooperation: no misrepresentation, individual contributions shown
ii.	2nd highest: no misrepresentation, only total contributions shown
iii.	3rd highest: misrepresentation, only total stated contributions shown
iv.	Lowest cooperation: misrepresentation, individual stated contributions shown

We also have an explicit prediction about the differences between the cultures:
3.	We expect that Chinese individuals (collectivist culture) are more likely to care about reputation concerns than individuals from the USA (individualist culture). Specific predictions:
a.	There will be a larger difference in both cooperation and misrepresentation between the treatments in which individual stated contributions are explicitly mentioned and where they are not in China than in the USA.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study (but the experimenters have no influence on the experimental subjects beyond the software through which they interact, and which was pre-designed). It is the nature of this experiment that the experimental treatment needs to be known to the participants – hence, there is no blinding.

question.value:
Our study is a between subjects design with four treatments in two cultures (2x2x2), with individuals nested in groups. Our treatments are 2x2 in the sense that they juxtapose the possibility to misrepresent with the degree of detail of the feedback about the (stated) cooperation of the fellow group members that is given to participants. Our (continuous) response variables are the degree of misrepresentation and the degree of contribution to the public good (i.e., cooperation). The interactions in our experiment are repeated, leading to the following predictor variables that will be included in the statistical analysis:
1.	Period (the ‘round number’ of the repeated interaction)
2.	The total contribution of all interaction partners in the previous period
3.	The total degree of misrepresentation of all interaction partners in the previous period (only in analyses on the treatment level for the treatments in which misrepresentation is possible)
4.	Possibility of misrepresentation (2 out of 4 treatments)
5.	Whether the individual (stated) contributions are fed back to the interaction partners or only the total (stated) contributions (2 out of 4 treatments)

q9.value: We will randomize the order of our treatments by drawing random numbers from a uniform distribution for each treatment, and then ordering them in ascending order of those random numbers.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit human subjects through online platforms. For the subjects in the USA population, we will recruit them through Amazon Mechanical Turk and limit their residence to the USA. In China, we are currently still searching for an appropriate way to do a similar recruitment through online platforms, but currently have encouraging signs that we will be able to do this through a Chinese company. Subjects will be paid a flat fee as well as an amount of money that depends on their decision in the experiment (for incentivation). We reserve some flexibility on the exact payment details, depending on how much we will end up having to pay the Chinese subjects (it is possible that there will be a minimum imposed for this). But our aim is to pay the USA subjects a flat fee of $2, and from the incentivized part between $2 and $4 extra. So on average, we aim to pay subjects $5 for a task that they do from home and that lasts for about 20 minutes. We aim to pay the Chinese subjects the same at purchasing power parity. We will exclude subjects under 18 years of age, and subjects that have participated in earlier experiments run by us.

q13.value: At present, our target sample size is 20 groups per treatment. Since we will have groups of 5, that means we will have 100 individuals per treatment, so 800 individuals in total. The bottleneck for sample size right now seems to be whether we can recruit enough Chinese participants through online platforms. If higher sample sizes turn out to be feasible, we will aim for 30 groups per treatment (1200 individuals in total). We aim for a minimum sample size of 600 individuals (15 groups per treatment).

q14.value: Right now, we have not much to go on in terms of the magnitude of the expected effects. A sample of 20 groups per treatment is relatively large, and will likely allow us to detect effects if they are there. We are currently still unclear how difficult it will be to get such large samples in China, which has led to the consideration to not increase the envisioned sample size much further, but if sampling in China turns out to be relatively easy, we will try to recruit 30 groups per treatment.

question.value:
The variables we will manipulate are:
1.	Possibility to misrepresent contributions in the PGG
2.	Degree of detail in the feedback of the stated contributions of fellow group members
3.	Culture (this is not a truly ‘manipulated’ variable of course – we just run the same experiment in two different cultures).
We will also vary the multiplication factor between rounds, but we will not inform the participants of the actual multiplication factor in any given round (they will know the range in which it falls). This is done so that the participants cannot calculate whether and to what extent their interaction partners have misrepresented their contributions.

We will measure:
1.	Degree of contribution to the public good (i.e., cooperation)
2.	Degree of misrepresentation of the contribution to the public good (i.e., difference between actual contribution and stated contribution)
N/A

Hypothesis 1: the possibility of misrepresentation undermines cooperation. 
We will check whether the possibility to misrepresent affects cooperation, by building a linear mixed effects model to predict degree of contribution (cooperation) with the following fixed predictors:
1.	Natural cubic spline of period
2.	Possibility to misrepresent
3.	Detail of feedback on the (stated) contributions of others
4.	Culture
5.	Natural cubic spline of total contribution of all fellow group members in the previous round
and as random effects individual nested in group.
In a first model, we will include all two-way interaction terms between the fixed variables and the three-way interaction between culture, the possibility for misrepresentation and the possibility for reputation (see Hypothesis 5), and then use backwards elimination to arrive at the best model based on Bayes’ Information Criterion (BIC). Note that we use splines for the continuous predictors because a linear model is not appropriate given that our response variable is bound between 0 and the maximum contribution. If the final model shows that the possibility to misrepresent significantly affected cooperation levels, this will be interpreted as support for this hypothesis.

Hypothesis 2: the degree of misrepresentation negatively affects cooperation. 
We will also investigate the quantitative effect of misrepresentation on cooperation. For this, we will not be able to include the treatments in which misrepresentation is not possible, so we will work with a subset of the data (only the two treatments in which misrepresentation was possible) and run a statistical model exactly as the one described under Hypothesis 1, but including one extra predictor variable:
1.	Natural cubic spline of total misrepresentation of all fellow group members in the previous round
We will interpret the effect of the degree of misrepresentation using prediction plots based on this model (interpreting the ‘significance’ of the spline terms is not that informative). Specifically, we will compute predictions (and prediction intervals) of contributions based on our model, systematically varying the total misrepresentation of the fellow group members in the previous round, and for both treatments and cultures. We will hold the other predictors (previous contribution of fellow group members and period) constant at median values. 

Hypothesis 3: misrepresentation leads to more misrepresentation
To test this hypothesis, we will run a model similar to the model used for hypothesis 2, but instead of degree of contribution as the response variable we will have the degree of misrepresentation as the response variable. We will interpret the effect of misrepresentation of fellow group members in the previous round on misrepresentation in the current round using the same approach as described there.

Hypothesis 4: the possibility for reputation interacts with the possibility for misrepresentation
To test this hypothesis, we will use the model described for hypothesis 1, and check whether there is a significant interaction between the possibility for reputation and the possibility for misrepresentation. Specifically, we expect that the possibility for reputation increases cooperation when misrepresentation is not possible, but decreases cooperation when misrepresentation is possible.  

Hypothesis 5: reputation is more important in China than in the USA, both as a driver of cooperation when misrepresentation is not possible, and as a driver of misrepresentation when it is possible (and therefore undermining cooperation more in that case).
We will test this hypothesis using the model described under hypothesis 1. We will test if there is a significant three-way interaction between culture, the possibility for misrepresentation and the possibility for reputation. Specifically, we expect the interaction between the possibility for misrepresentation and the possibility for reputation to be stronger in China than in the USA.

q20.value: We do not plan on transforming the response variables. We will use sum coding for the categorical predictors.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<0.05 criterion for determining if our categorical factors have a significant effect on the response variables (hypotheses 1, 4 and 5). For determining whether the continuous variables have an important effect, we will rely on careful graphical interpretation of prediction plots. This is because the estimates and p-values of the spline components are not straightforward to interpret. Hence, we will visualize the effects of these continuous variables and present these when we report our analysis outcomes.

q22.value: It is always possible that some individuals fail to make their decisions before the timer ends. It is not a big problem if this happens once or twice, but if it happens too much it will affect the data too much. Therefore, we will exclude groups that include at least one individual who has made fewer than half the requested decisions in time.

q23.value: If individuals did not make decisions in some rounds, those data points will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value: We will conduct exploratory analyses on the degree to which there are individual differences in misrepresentation, whether the individual variation is different between the cultures, whether there are correlations between misrepresentation and contribution, and whether that correlation is different between cultures.

registration_responses.q1: A cross-cultural study of misrepresenting contributions in a public goods game
registration_responses.q2: Pieter van den Berg, Siyuan Liu, Tom Wenseleers, Zhang, Jianlei
registration_responses.q3: Individuals may have direct strategic and more general reputation-related reasons for misrepresenting their contributions to common cooperative projects. We investigate the effects of being able to misrepresent contributions in a public goods game, in a large interactive online decision making experiment conducted in two different cultures (China and USA). By implementing different experimental treatments, we aim to test our expectation that the possibility for misrepresenting undermines cooperation and whether this effect is even stronger if it is possible to build a personal reputation. For these hypotheses, the subject pools in China and the USA should be considered as independent replications. In addition, we will test our expectation that reputation concerns are relatively stronger in China, so that the possibility for misrepresentation disproportionally undermines cooperation when reputation concerns are relevant.
registration_responses.q4:
We have a number of expectations about the results of the experiment within both cultures:
1.	We expect that the degree of misrepresentation undermines cooperation. Specific predictions: 
a.	There will be less cooperation in the treatments in which misrepresentation is possible
b.	There will be less cooperation if there was more misrepresentation in the previous round
c.	There will be more misrepresentation if there was more misrepresentation in the previous round

2.	We expect that individuals are motivated to misrepresent both by direct strategic concerns (to elicit future cooperation from interaction partners) and by more general reputational concerns (to be seen as a generally cooperative person). We designed our experiment in such a way that we can tease the effects of these two motivations apart. We have two treatments in which misrepresentation is possible and two in which it is not possible. For both these pairs of treatments, in one of them only the total stated contributions of all interaction partners are relayed the group members after decisions are made, so reputation concerns are less important. In the other, individual stated contributions are fed back to the interaction partners, leading to a higher importance of reputation concerns. Specific predictions: 
a.	we expect more cooperation in the treatment where individual stated contributions are specifically mentioned and where misrepresentation is not possible, than in the treatment without misrepresentation that only mentions total contributions.
b.	We expect more misrepresentation in the treatment where individual stated contributions are mentioned than where they are not, but lower cooperation (so when misrepresentation is possible, we expect the opposite effect of reputation as under a)
c.	We expect an interaction between the possibility of misrepresentation and the showing of individual contributions, in such a way that the differences in cooperation rates between the experimental treatments are as follows:
i.	Highest cooperation: no misrepresentation, individual contributions shown
ii.	2nd highest: no misrepresentation, only total contributions shown
iii.	3rd highest: misrepresentation, only total stated contributions shown
iv.	Lowest cooperation: misrepresentation, individual stated contributions shown

We also have an explicit prediction about the differences between the cultures:
3.	We expect that Chinese individuals (collectivist culture) are more likely to care about reputation concerns than individuals from the USA (individualist culture). Specific predictions:
a.	There will be a larger difference in both cooperation and misrepresentation between the treatments in which individual stated contributions are explicitly mentioned and where they are not in China than in the USA.

q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: No blinding is involved in this study (but the experimenters have no influence on the experimental subjects beyond the software through which they interact, and which was pre-designed). It is the nature of this experiment that the experimental treatment needs to be known to the participants – hence, there is no blinding.
registration_responses.q9: We will randomize the order of our treatments by drawing random numbers from a uniform distribution for each treatment, and then ordering them in ascending order of those random numbers.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: At present, our target sample size is 20 groups per treatment. Since we will have groups of 5, that means we will have 100 individuals per treatment, so 800 individuals in total. The bottleneck for sample size right now seems to be whether we can recruit enough Chinese participants through online platforms. If higher sample sizes turn out to be feasible, we will aim for 30 groups per treatment (1200 individuals in total). We aim for a minimum sample size of 600 individuals (15 groups per treatment).
registration_responses.q14: Right now, we have not much to go on in terms of the magnitude of the expected effects. A sample of 20 groups per treatment is relatively large, and will likely allow us to detect effects if they are there. We are currently still unclear how difficult it will be to get such large samples in China, which has led to the consideration to not increase the envisioned sample size much further, but if sampling in China turns out to be relatively easy, we will try to recruit 30 groups per treatment.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Our study is a between subjects design with four treatments in two cultures (2x2x2), with individuals nested in groups. Our treatments are 2x2 in the sense that they juxtapose the possibility to misrepresent with the degree of detail of the feedback about the (stated) cooperation of the fellow group members that is given to participants. Our (continuous) response variables are the degree of misrepresentation and the degree of contribution to the public good (i.e., cooperation). The interactions in our experiment are repeated, leading to the following predictor variables that will be included in the statistical analysis:
1.	Period (the ‘round number’ of the repeated interaction)
2.	The total contribution of all interaction partners in the previous period
3.	The total degree of misrepresentation of all interaction partners in the previous period (only in analyses on the treatment level for the treatments in which misrepresentation is possible)
4.	Possibility of misrepresentation (2 out of 4 treatments)
5.	Whether the individual (stated) contributions are fed back to the interaction partners or only the total (stated) contributions (2 out of 4 treatments)
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit human subjects through online platforms. For the subjects in the USA population, we will recruit them through Amazon Mechanical Turk and limit their residence to the USA. In China, we are currently still searching for an appropriate way to do a similar recruitment through online platforms, but currently have encouraging signs that we will be able to do this through a Chinese company. Subjects will be paid a flat fee as well as an amount of money that depends on their decision in the experiment (for incentivation). We reserve some flexibility on the exact payment details, depending on how much we will end up having to pay the Chinese subjects (it is possible that there will be a minimum imposed for this). But our aim is to pay the USA subjects a flat fee of $2, and from the incentivized part between $2 and $4 extra. So on average, we aim to pay subjects $5 for a task that they do from home and that lasts for about 20 minutes. We aim to pay the Chinese subjects the same at purchasing power parity. We will exclude subjects under 18 years of age, and subjects that have participated in earlier experiments run by us.
registration_responses.q16.question:
The variables we will manipulate are:
1.	Possibility to misrepresent contributions in the PGG
2.	Degree of detail in the feedback of the stated contributions of fellow group members
3.	Culture (this is not a truly ‘manipulated’ variable of course – we just run the same experiment in two different cultures).
We will also vary the multiplication factor between rounds, but we will not inform the participants of the actual multiplication factor in any given round (they will know the range in which it falls). This is done so that the participants cannot calculate whether and to what extent their interaction partners have misrepresented their contributions.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We will measure:
1.	Degree of contribution to the public good (i.e., cooperation)
2.	Degree of misrepresentation of the contribution to the public good (i.e., difference between actual contribution and stated contribution)

registration_responses.q19.question:
Hypothesis 1: the possibility of misrepresentation undermines cooperation. 
We will check whether the possibility to misrepresent affects cooperation, by building a linear mixed effects model to predict degree of contribution (cooperation) with the following fixed predictors:
1.	Natural cubic spline of period
2.	Possibility to misrepresent
3.	Detail of feedback on the (stated) contributions of others
4.	Culture
5.	Natural cubic spline of total contribution of all fellow group members in the previous round
and as random effects individual nested in group.
In a first model, we will include all two-way interaction terms between the fixed variables and the three-way interaction between culture, the possibility for misrepresentation and the possibility for reputation (see Hypothesis 5), and then use backwards elimination to arrive at the best model based on Bayes’ Information Criterion (BIC). Note that we use splines for the continuous predictors because a linear model is not appropriate given that our response variable is bound between 0 and the maximum contribution. If the final model shows that the possibility to misrepresent significantly affected cooperation levels, this will be interpreted as support for this hypothesis.

Hypothesis 2: the degree of misrepresentation negatively affects cooperation. 
We will also investigate the quantitative effect of misrepresentation on cooperation. For this, we will not be able to include the treatments in which misrepresentation is not possible, so we will work with a subset of the data (only the two treatments in which misrepresentation was possible) and run a statistical model exactly as the one described under Hypothesis 1, but including one extra predictor variable:
1.	Natural cubic spline of total misrepresentation of all fellow group members in the previous round
We will interpret the effect of the degree of misrepresentation using prediction plots based on this model (interpreting the ‘significance’ of the spline terms is not that informative). Specifically, we will compute predictions (and prediction intervals) of contributions based on our model, systematically varying the total misrepresentation of the fellow group members in the previous round, and for both treatments and cultures. We will hold the other predictors (previous contribution of fellow group members and period) constant at median values. 

Hypothesis 3: misrepresentation leads to more misrepresentation
To test this hypothesis, we will run a model similar to the model used for hypothesis 2, but instead of degree of contribution as the response variable we will have the degree of misrepresentation as the response variable. We will interpret the effect of misrepresentation of fellow group members in the previous round on misrepresentation in the current round using the same approach as described there.

Hypothesis 4: the possibility for reputation interacts with the possibility for misrepresentation
To test this hypothesis, we will use the model described for hypothesis 1, and check whether there is a significant interaction between the possibility for reputation and the possibility for misrepresentation. Specifically, we expect that the possibility for reputation increases cooperation when misrepresentation is not possible, but decreases cooperation when misrepresentation is possible.  

Hypothesis 5: reputation is more important in China than in the USA, both as a driver of cooperation when misrepresentation is not possible, and as a driver of misrepresentation when it is possible (and therefore undermining cooperation more in that case).
We will test this hypothesis using the model described under hypothesis 1. We will test if there is a significant three-way interaction between culture, the possibility for misrepresentation and the possibility for reputation. Specifically, we expect the interaction between the possibility for misrepresentation and the possibility for reputation to be stronger in China than in the USA.

attributes.title: Effects of mindfulness vs. distraction on pain experience and the moderating effect of pain catastrophizing
attributes.description: Although the effects of Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBIs) have been extensively investigated, there is less information on potential negative effects of MBIs. Specifically, it is unclear for whom MBIs might be beneficial and for whom it may lead to undesirable effects. Therefore, the focus of our study is to explore whether a short mindfulness induction, in comparison to a distraction condition, has differential effects on experimental pain perception and state affect in participants with lower levels of pain catastrophizing/repetitive negative thinking compared to those with higher levels of pain catastrophizing/repetitive negative thinking. Participants will be randomised to the mindfulness or distraction condition. While receiving repeated heat stimuli, participants will listen to the corresponding experimental induction via headphones. Afterwards, their pain perception and state affect will be examined. Two weeks later, participants’ remembered pain and affect during the experimental session will be assessed.

q1.value: Merle Kock, Filip Raes, Marta Walentynowicz

q2.value:
1.	For participants low on pain catastrophizing, affective pain perception will be more pronounced in the mindfulness group compared to the distraction group. For participants high on pain catastrophizing, we expect the opposite effect (affective pain perception will be more pronounced in the distraction group compared to the mindfulness group).

2.	For repetitive negative thinking, we expect a similar, but possibly weaker interaction effect (higher affective pain perception in mindfulness group for participants low in repetitive negative thinking, opposite effect for those low on repetitive negative thinking) given that pain catastrophizing constitutes only one aspect of repetitive negative thinking.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study is a replication and extension of a previous study by Prins and colleagues (Prins, Decuypere, & van Damme, 2014) and employs a randomised between-subjects design. Participants will be tested individually according to the following procedure:

Preparatory phase: Upon arrival in the lab, participants will be randomly allocated to the mindfulness or distraction induction. Afterwards, participants will complete questionnaires assessing demographic information, past and current pain experiences (MPQ-DV), pain catastrophizing (PCS), repetitive negative thinking (PTQ), and dispositional mindfulness (MAAS, AAQ-II, CHIME-SF). Participants will also rate their affective experience in the present moment via 14 emotional adjectives to serve as a baseline measure. A thermode (3 x 3 cm) will be positioned on the non-dominant lower arm just above the wrist to enable delivery of the heat stimuli. 

Baseline measurements: To familiarise participants with the experimental heat stimuli, three heat stimuli will be presented on the non-dominant lower arm and participants will be asked to rate them in terms of pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear (PE2). Subsequently, they will follow a short relaxation exercise to ensure that the potential effects induced by the mindfulness exercise are specific effects of mindfulness rather than the relaxation component of mindfulness. Afterwards, participants will again rate their affective experience to test for changes induced by the relaxation exercise.

Experimental phase: The thermode will be positioned on the dominant lower arm. Participants will be instructed to listen carefully to the recording and follow the instructions. They will be told that they will have to answer questions about the recordings later in the experiment. Subsequently, participants will listen to the induction tapes via headphone while they receive 7 pain stimuli on the dominant lower arm. Each stimulus will have a duration of 4 seconds, with a 32°C baseline temperature, a 46°C peak temperature, and a 7°C/s temperature change rate. The stimuli will be administered throughout a period of 10 minutes to enable a simultaneous presentation of mindfulness-based instructions that optimally matches the administration schedule. Upon completion, participants will rate their pain experience during the pain induction using the questionnaire developed by the lab of Prins and colleagues (PE1) as well as items on pleasantness, intensity, pain and fear (PE2). Moreover, participants will complete the affect questionnaire again. To check whether the manipulation was successful, participants will complete a subset of items based on the CHIME.

After the experiment: The thermode will be removed and the participant will be thanked for participation. They will be reminded to complete the questionnaires that will be sent to them via e-mail two weeks later. Finally, participants will be given contact details for different counseling services.

Two weeks after the experimental session:  Participants will receive an e-mail, asking them again to rate their remembered pain experience and affect during the pain induction in the experimental session using the 4 items on pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear (PE2) as well as the affect questionnaire. They will also rate their pain at the present moment as well as frequency and intrusiveness of their pain memory in the past week. Upon completion of the questionnaires, participants will receive a debriefing sheet and will be compensated for their efforts.

q7.value: Participants will be randomised to the mindfulness group or control group using block randomisation performed with a web application.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Recruitment: Participants will be recruited via poster advertisement around the university campus of KU Leuven, social media, such as the Facebook page advertising experiments conducted in our faculty (Psychology and Educational Sciences), the departmental Experimental Management System (EMS) as well as via word of mouth. Interested participants will be informed about the experimental procedure, the estimated duration of the study and participant reimbursement. 

Exclusion Criteria: Participants meeting at least one of the following criteria will be excluded from participation: (1) below 16 years of age; (2) current pain of at least moderate intensity based on the McGill Pain Questionnaire; (3) weekly practice of some form of meditation; (4) cardiovascular disease; (5) insufficient knowledge of the Dutch language.

Compensation: As compensation for their efforts, participants will receive 1 course credit or a monetary reward of 8€ per hour.

q11.value: Based on a power calculation assuming a medium effect size, a power of 80% and α = 0.05, we aim to recruit 108 participants (54 per group).

q12.value: The original study by Prins et al. (2014), on which our study is built on, reported a medium effect size for the interaction effect of group and pain catastrophizing. Thus, we performed a power analysis assuming a medium effect size, a power of 80% and α = 0.05 using the software program G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007).

question.value:
Mindfulness induction
Participants in the mindfulness group will listen to pre-recorded instructions described by Prins et al. (2014), presented through headphones. The manipulation aims to cultivate four processes that are essential in mindfulness therapies: contact with the present moment, acceptance, defusion and self as context. In the context of the pain induction, participants will be encouraged to experience the painful sensation (present moment awareness) with an open mindset (acceptance). They will be asked to label the process (‘this is painful’) to promote defusion. In the absence of any stimuli, participants will be able to ‘rest’ in awareness (self as context). At the beginning and every time their thoughts drift away, participants will be instructed to direct their attention to the breathing and bodily sensations. Participants will be reminded to incorporate a gentle and mild attitude towards their experience even when drifting away. Moreover, it will be pointed out that the task is not to reach any particular goal and that participants do not have to change anything during the exercise. Instructions will be synchronised with stimulus presentation to enable an optimal guidance.

Distraction induction
Participants in the distraction group will not receive instructions about how to cope with the pain. Instead, they will be provided with recordings of two fairytales through headphones, pre-recorded by the same voice as the mindfulness instructions.

Pain Experience. Pain experience of the experimental heat stimuli will serve as the primary outcome variable. This will be assessed via two self-report questionnaires. The first questionnaire (PE1), developed by Goubert and colleagues (2004), measures 4 different aspects of pain: sensory pain, affective pain, attention to the pain, and general anxiety. Its 20 items will be rated on 11-point Likert scales. This questionnaire will be completed directly after the experimental pain induction. The second questionnaire (PE2), adopted from Prins and colleagues (2014), assesses pleasantness, intensity, pain and fear on an 11-point Likert scale. This questionnaire will be completed after the test stimuli (baseline), after the experimental pain induction (post-assessment) and at 2-weeks follow-up to test for changes of pain experience over time. At the follow-up assessment point, participants will be additionally asked about the frequency and intrusiveness of their memory of the experimental heat pain. 

State Affect. To assess state affect as our secondary outcome variable, we designed a questionnaire based on the circumplex model of emotions. The questionnaire consists of 14 emotion adjectives (e.g. energetic, relaxed, angry, down) of varying valence and arousal adapted from Yik and colleagues (Yik, Russell, & Steiger, 2011). Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = not at all to 5  = very much. Separate scores for positive affect (PA) and negative affect (NA) will be calculated by summing up the respective item scores.

Pain Catastrophizing. To assess participants’ dispositional pain catastrophizing as a moderator variable, the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS; Sullivan, Bishop, & Pivik, 1995; van Damme et al., 2000) will be used. The questionnaire asks participants to reflect on past painful experiences and rate the degree to which they endorsed each of the 13 thoughts or feelings during pain (e.g. “I become afraid that the pain may get worse”) in a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = not at all to 4 = all the time.  The PCS has shown good reliability and validity in non-clinical populations (van Damme, Crombez, Bijttebier, Goubert, & van Houdenhove, 2002).

Repetitive negative thinking. As a second moderator variable, repetitive negative thinking will be assessed using the Perseverative Thinking Questionnaire (PTQ; Ehring et al., 2011). The 15-item questionnaire is scored on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = never to 4 = almost always with higher scores reflecting higher levels of repetitive negative thinking. The Dutch version of the PTQ evidenced good internal consistency and validity (Ehring, Raes, Weidacker, & Emmelkamp, 2012).

Dispositional Mindfulness. To measure individual differences in dispositional mindfulness, three questionnaires will be administered. To assess their open awareness of and attention to the present moment, participants will complete the Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale (MAAS; Brown & Ryan, 2003). Its 15 items (e.g. “I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until sometime later”) are rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = almost always to 6 = almost never with higher scores indicating higher levels of mindfulness. The MAAS evidenced strong psychometric properties (Brown & Ryan, 2003). 
To measure participants’ psychological flexibility, the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire-II (AAQ-II; Bond et al., 2011) will be used. Its 10 items are rated on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = never true to 7 = always true with a higher score indicating higher acceptance and less experiential avoidance (Bond et al., 2011). The AAQ-II has shown strong psychometric properties (Jacobs, Kleen, Groot, & A-Tjak, 2008).
To provide a measure of all mindfulness aspects, we will additionally include the Short Form of the Comprehensive Inventory of Mindfulness Experiences (CHIME-SF; Cladder-Micus et al., 2019). It consists of eight subscales: inner awareness, outer awareness, acting with awareness, acceptance, decentering/nonreactivity, openness, relativity, and insight. The 24-item questionnaire is scored on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = almost never to 6 = almost always with higher scores on each subscale representing higher levels of mindfulness skills. The CHIME-SF evidenced strong reliability and validity in clinical and non-clinical samples (Cladder-Micus et al., 2019). 

Past and current pain experience. To control for effects of pain present before the start of the experiment, past and current pain experience will be measured using an adapted version of the McGill Pain Questionnaire for the Dutch language (MPV-DV; Vanderiet, Adriaensen, Carton, & Vertommen, 1987) that we adopted from the original study by Prins et al. (2014).  

Manipulation check. To check whether the mindfulness manipulation was successful, we constructed a questionnaire adapted from the Comprehensive Inventory of Mindfulness Experiences (CHIME and CHIME-A; Cladder-Micus et al., 2019; Johnson, Burke, Brinkman, & Wade, 2017), the Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, 2003) and the mindfulness induction transcript itself. The scale consists of 10 items, with at least one item for the CHIME subscales decentering/nonreactivity, inner awareness, acting with awareness, openness and acceptance. Items were chosen based on their suitability as a state measure of mindfulness and their fit with respect to the mindfulness manipulation.
Regarding the state affect questionnaire, separate scores for positive affect (PA) and negative affect (NA) will be calculated by summing up the respective item scores.

A series of ANOVAs with baseline self-report measures (PE2, PA, NA, MPQ-DV, PCS, PTQ, MAAS, AAQ-II, CHIME-SF) as dependent variable and group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor will be performed to check for pre-existing differences between the groups. If a significant difference is detected, the corresponding variable will be included as a covariate in the subsequent analyses. To check if the mindfulness manipulation was successful, another ANOVA with manipulation check scores as dependent variable and group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor will be conducted. To test whether the relaxation exercise had an effect on self-reported affect, an ANOVA with affect scores after the relaxation exercise as dependent variable and group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor will be performed. 

For the main analysis testing whether pain catastrophizing moderates the effect of mindfulness on pain experience (Hypothesis 1), a multivariate general linear model will be used, with self-reported pain experience (PE1: sensory pain, affective pain, and general anxiety) as dependent variable, and group (mindfulness vs. distraction), pain catastrophizing and the interaction between the two variables as between-subjects factors. To examine whether repetitive negative thinking also moderates the effect of mindfulness on pain experience (Hypothesis 2), a similar multivariate general linear model will be performed, with pain experience (PE1) as dependent variable, and group (mindfulness vs. distraction), repetitive negative thinking and the interaction of the two variables as between-subjects factors. As an additional test of both hypotheses, the same multivariate general linear model analyses will be performed, this time with the pain experience PE2 scores (pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear) at post-intervention as dependent variables.

q19.value: For all analyses, the standard p < .05 criterion will be used. Two-tailed statistical tests including p-values, effect sizes and confidence intervals will be reported throughout. Bonferroni corrections will be applied to adjust for multiple testing, especially for the preparatory ANOVA analyses and to disentangle the effects on the individual dependent variables in the main analyses. For exploratory analyses, the need for further replication and extension of the analyses will be acknowledged in the final paper.

q20.value: Normality of all data will be explored using the Shapiro-Wilk test and the frequency distribution for visual inspection. To identify outliers, which are defined as cases over 3 standard deviations away from the group mean, Boxplots will be used. Each outlier will be assigned a value that is one unit larger or smaller than the second most extreme value in the distribution, following recommendations by Tabachnick & Fidell (2000). To check for violations of homogeneity of variances, Levene’s test will be applied to all dependent variables. For the multivariate models, Box’s test will be used to additionally compare variance-covariance matrices across groups.

q21.value: If a participant does not complete the follow-up assessment, that participant will still be included in the other analyses not concerning follow-up data.

q22.value: As an exploratory analysis of the effect of mindfulness on pain experience at follow-up, a repeated measures ANOVA with pain experience PE2 scores (pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear) as dependent variable, group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor, and time (post-experimental vs. follow-up) as within-subjects factor. Additional predictors, such as pain catastrophizing or repetitive negative thinking, may be added to the model at a later stage. To explore the effect of mindfulness vs. distraction on state affect, a repeated measures ANOVA with self-reported positive affect/negative affect as dependent variable, group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor, and time (baseline vs. post-experimental vs. follow-up) as within-subjects factor. Planned contrasts will be performed to disentangle the effect of mindfulness over time. For the effect of the manipulation on affective symptom perception, a planned contrast between baseline and post-experimental affect scores will be run. For the effect of the manipulation on affective symptom memory, a planned contrast between post-experimental and follow-up affect measures will be performed.

q23.value:
The study is a replication and extension of a previous study by Prins and colleagues (Prins, Decuypere, & van Damme, 2014).

registration_responses.q2:
1.	For participants low on pain catastrophizing, affective pain perception will be more pronounced in the mindfulness group compared to the distraction group. For participants high on pain catastrophizing, we expect the opposite effect (affective pain perception will be more pronounced in the distraction group compared to the mindfulness group).

2.	For repetitive negative thinking, we expect a similar, but possibly weaker interaction effect (higher affective pain perception in mindfulness group for participants low in repetitive negative thinking, opposite effect for those low on repetitive negative thinking) given that pain catastrophizing constitutes only one aspect of repetitive negative thinking.
registration_responses.q3: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: Participants will be randomised to the mindfulness group or control group using block randomisation performed with a web application.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Based on a power calculation assuming a medium effect size, a power of 80% and α = 0.05, we aim to recruit 108 participants (54 per group).
registration_responses.q12: The original study by Prins et al. (2014), on which our study is built on, reported a medium effect size for the interaction effect of group and pain catastrophizing. Thus, we performed a power analysis assuming a medium effect size, a power of 80% and α = 0.05 using the software program G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007).
registration_responses.q19: For all analyses, the standard p < .05 criterion will be used. Two-tailed statistical tests including p-values, effect sizes and confidence intervals will be reported throughout. Bonferroni corrections will be applied to adjust for multiple testing, especially for the preparatory ANOVA analyses and to disentangle the effects on the individual dependent variables in the main analyses. For exploratory analyses, the need for further replication and extension of the analyses will be acknowledged in the final paper.
registration_responses.q20: Normality of all data will be explored using the Shapiro-Wilk test and the frequency distribution for visual inspection. To identify outliers, which are defined as cases over 3 standard deviations away from the group mean, Boxplots will be used. Each outlier will be assigned a value that is one unit larger or smaller than the second most extreme value in the distribution, following recommendations by Tabachnick & Fidell (2000). To check for violations of homogeneity of variances, Levene’s test will be applied to all dependent variables. For the multivariate models, Box’s test will be used to additionally compare variance-covariance matrices across groups.
registration_responses.q21: If a participant does not complete the follow-up assessment, that participant will still be included in the other analyses not concerning follow-up data.
registration_responses.q22: As an exploratory analysis of the effect of mindfulness on pain experience at follow-up, a repeated measures ANOVA with pain experience PE2 scores (pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear) as dependent variable, group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor, and time (post-experimental vs. follow-up) as within-subjects factor. Additional predictors, such as pain catastrophizing or repetitive negative thinking, may be added to the model at a later stage. To explore the effect of mindfulness vs. distraction on state affect, a repeated measures ANOVA with self-reported positive affect/negative affect as dependent variable, group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor, and time (baseline vs. post-experimental vs. follow-up) as within-subjects factor. Planned contrasts will be performed to disentangle the effect of mindfulness over time. For the effect of the manipulation on affective symptom perception, a planned contrast between baseline and post-experimental affect scores will be run. For the effect of the manipulation on affective symptom memory, a planned contrast between post-experimental and follow-up affect measures will be performed.

registration_responses.q6.question:
The study is a replication and extension of a previous study by Prins and colleagues (Prins, Decuypere, & van Damme, 2014) and employs a randomised between-subjects design. Participants will be tested individually according to the following procedure:

Preparatory phase: Upon arrival in the lab, participants will be randomly allocated to the mindfulness or distraction induction. Afterwards, participants will complete questionnaires assessing demographic information, past and current pain experiences (MPQ-DV), pain catastrophizing (PCS), repetitive negative thinking (PTQ), and dispositional mindfulness (MAAS, AAQ-II, CHIME-SF). Participants will also rate their affective experience in the present moment via 14 emotional adjectives to serve as a baseline measure. A thermode (3 x 3 cm) will be positioned on the non-dominant lower arm just above the wrist to enable delivery of the heat stimuli. 

Baseline measurements: To familiarise participants with the experimental heat stimuli, three heat stimuli will be presented on the non-dominant lower arm and participants will be asked to rate them in terms of pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear (PE2). Subsequently, they will follow a short relaxation exercise to ensure that the potential effects induced by the mindfulness exercise are specific effects of mindfulness rather than the relaxation component of mindfulness. Afterwards, participants will again rate their affective experience to test for changes induced by the relaxation exercise.

Experimental phase: The thermode will be positioned on the dominant lower arm. Participants will be instructed to listen carefully to the recording and follow the instructions. They will be told that they will have to answer questions about the recordings later in the experiment. Subsequently, participants will listen to the induction tapes via headphone while they receive 7 pain stimuli on the dominant lower arm. Each stimulus will have a duration of 4 seconds, with a 32°C baseline temperature, a 46°C peak temperature, and a 7°C/s temperature change rate. The stimuli will be administered throughout a period of 10 minutes to enable a simultaneous presentation of mindfulness-based instructions that optimally matches the administration schedule. Upon completion, participants will rate their pain experience during the pain induction using the questionnaire developed by the lab of Prins and colleagues (PE1) as well as items on pleasantness, intensity, pain and fear (PE2). Moreover, participants will complete the affect questionnaire again. To check whether the manipulation was successful, participants will complete a subset of items based on the CHIME.

After the experiment: The thermode will be removed and the participant will be thanked for participation. They will be reminded to complete the questionnaires that will be sent to them via e-mail two weeks later. Finally, participants will be given contact details for different counseling services.

Two weeks after the experimental session:  Participants will receive an e-mail, asking them again to rate their remembered pain experience and affect during the pain induction in the experimental session using the 4 items on pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear (PE2) as well as the affect questionnaire. They will also rate their pain at the present moment as well as frequency and intrusiveness of their pain memory in the past week. Upon completion of the questionnaires, participants will receive a debriefing sheet and will be compensated for their efforts.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Recruitment: Participants will be recruited via poster advertisement around the university campus of KU Leuven, social media, such as the Facebook page advertising experiments conducted in our faculty (Psychology and Educational Sciences), the departmental Experimental Management System (EMS) as well as via word of mouth. Interested participants will be informed about the experimental procedure, the estimated duration of the study and participant reimbursement. 

Exclusion Criteria: Participants meeting at least one of the following criteria will be excluded from participation: (1) below 16 years of age; (2) current pain of at least moderate intensity based on the McGill Pain Questionnaire; (3) weekly practice of some form of meditation; (4) cardiovascular disease; (5) insufficient knowledge of the Dutch language.

Compensation: As compensation for their efforts, participants will receive 1 course credit or a monetary reward of 8€ per hour.
registration_responses.q14.question:
Mindfulness induction
Participants in the mindfulness group will listen to pre-recorded instructions described by Prins et al. (2014), presented through headphones. The manipulation aims to cultivate four processes that are essential in mindfulness therapies: contact with the present moment, acceptance, defusion and self as context. In the context of the pain induction, participants will be encouraged to experience the painful sensation (present moment awareness) with an open mindset (acceptance). They will be asked to label the process (‘this is painful’) to promote defusion. In the absence of any stimuli, participants will be able to ‘rest’ in awareness (self as context). At the beginning and every time their thoughts drift away, participants will be instructed to direct their attention to the breathing and bodily sensations. Participants will be reminded to incorporate a gentle and mild attitude towards their experience even when drifting away. Moreover, it will be pointed out that the task is not to reach any particular goal and that participants do not have to change anything during the exercise. Instructions will be synchronised with stimulus presentation to enable an optimal guidance.

Distraction induction
Participants in the distraction group will not receive instructions about how to cope with the pain. Instead, they will be provided with recordings of two fairytales through headphones, pre-recorded by the same voice as the mindfulness instructions.
registration_responses.q15.question:
Pain Experience. Pain experience of the experimental heat stimuli will serve as the primary outcome variable. This will be assessed via two self-report questionnaires. The first questionnaire (PE1), developed by Goubert and colleagues (2004), measures 4 different aspects of pain: sensory pain, affective pain, attention to the pain, and general anxiety. Its 20 items will be rated on 11-point Likert scales. This questionnaire will be completed directly after the experimental pain induction. The second questionnaire (PE2), adopted from Prins and colleagues (2014), assesses pleasantness, intensity, pain and fear on an 11-point Likert scale. This questionnaire will be completed after the test stimuli (baseline), after the experimental pain induction (post-assessment) and at 2-weeks follow-up to test for changes of pain experience over time. At the follow-up assessment point, participants will be additionally asked about the frequency and intrusiveness of their memory of the experimental heat pain. 

State Affect. To assess state affect as our secondary outcome variable, we designed a questionnaire based on the circumplex model of emotions. The questionnaire consists of 14 emotion adjectives (e.g. energetic, relaxed, angry, down) of varying valence and arousal adapted from Yik and colleagues (Yik, Russell, & Steiger, 2011). Items are rated on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = not at all to 5  = very much. Separate scores for positive affect (PA) and negative affect (NA) will be calculated by summing up the respective item scores.

Pain Catastrophizing. To assess participants’ dispositional pain catastrophizing as a moderator variable, the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (PCS; Sullivan, Bishop, & Pivik, 1995; van Damme et al., 2000) will be used. The questionnaire asks participants to reflect on past painful experiences and rate the degree to which they endorsed each of the 13 thoughts or feelings during pain (e.g. “I become afraid that the pain may get worse”) in a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = not at all to 4 = all the time.  The PCS has shown good reliability and validity in non-clinical populations (van Damme, Crombez, Bijttebier, Goubert, & van Houdenhove, 2002).

Repetitive negative thinking. As a second moderator variable, repetitive negative thinking will be assessed using the Perseverative Thinking Questionnaire (PTQ; Ehring et al., 2011). The 15-item questionnaire is scored on a 4-point Likert scale ranging from 0 = never to 4 = almost always with higher scores reflecting higher levels of repetitive negative thinking. The Dutch version of the PTQ evidenced good internal consistency and validity (Ehring, Raes, Weidacker, & Emmelkamp, 2012).

Dispositional Mindfulness. To measure individual differences in dispositional mindfulness, three questionnaires will be administered. To assess their open awareness of and attention to the present moment, participants will complete the Mindful Attention and Awareness Scale (MAAS; Brown & Ryan, 2003). Its 15 items (e.g. “I could be experiencing some emotion and not be conscious of it until sometime later”) are rated on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = almost always to 6 = almost never with higher scores indicating higher levels of mindfulness. The MAAS evidenced strong psychometric properties (Brown & Ryan, 2003). 
To measure participants’ psychological flexibility, the Acceptance and Action Questionnaire-II (AAQ-II; Bond et al., 2011) will be used. Its 10 items are rated on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = never true to 7 = always true with a higher score indicating higher acceptance and less experiential avoidance (Bond et al., 2011). The AAQ-II has shown strong psychometric properties (Jacobs, Kleen, Groot, & A-Tjak, 2008).
To provide a measure of all mindfulness aspects, we will additionally include the Short Form of the Comprehensive Inventory of Mindfulness Experiences (CHIME-SF; Cladder-Micus et al., 2019). It consists of eight subscales: inner awareness, outer awareness, acting with awareness, acceptance, decentering/nonreactivity, openness, relativity, and insight. The 24-item questionnaire is scored on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = almost never to 6 = almost always with higher scores on each subscale representing higher levels of mindfulness skills. The CHIME-SF evidenced strong reliability and validity in clinical and non-clinical samples (Cladder-Micus et al., 2019). 

Past and current pain experience. To control for effects of pain present before the start of the experiment, past and current pain experience will be measured using an adapted version of the McGill Pain Questionnaire for the Dutch language (MPV-DV; Vanderiet, Adriaensen, Carton, & Vertommen, 1987) that we adopted from the original study by Prins et al. (2014).  

Manipulation check. To check whether the mindfulness manipulation was successful, we constructed a questionnaire adapted from the Comprehensive Inventory of Mindfulness Experiences (CHIME and CHIME-A; Cladder-Micus et al., 2019; Johnson, Burke, Brinkman, & Wade, 2017), the Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, 2003) and the mindfulness induction transcript itself. The scale consists of 10 items, with at least one item for the CHIME subscales decentering/nonreactivity, inner awareness, acting with awareness, openness and acceptance. Items were chosen based on their suitability as a state measure of mindfulness and their fit with respect to the mindfulness manipulation.
registration_responses.q16.question: Regarding the state affect questionnaire, separate scores for positive affect (PA) and negative affect (NA) will be calculated by summing up the respective item scores.
registration_responses.q17.question:
A series of ANOVAs with baseline self-report measures (PE2, PA, NA, MPQ-DV, PCS, PTQ, MAAS, AAQ-II, CHIME-SF) as dependent variable and group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor will be performed to check for pre-existing differences between the groups. If a significant difference is detected, the corresponding variable will be included as a covariate in the subsequent analyses. To check if the mindfulness manipulation was successful, another ANOVA with manipulation check scores as dependent variable and group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor will be conducted. To test whether the relaxation exercise had an effect on self-reported affect, an ANOVA with affect scores after the relaxation exercise as dependent variable and group (mindfulness vs. distraction) as between-subjects factor will be performed. 

For the main analysis testing whether pain catastrophizing moderates the effect of mindfulness on pain experience (Hypothesis 1), a multivariate general linear model will be used, with self-reported pain experience (PE1: sensory pain, affective pain, and general anxiety) as dependent variable, and group (mindfulness vs. distraction), pain catastrophizing and the interaction between the two variables as between-subjects factors. To examine whether repetitive negative thinking also moderates the effect of mindfulness on pain experience (Hypothesis 2), a similar multivariate general linear model will be performed, with pain experience (PE1) as dependent variable, and group (mindfulness vs. distraction), repetitive negative thinking and the interaction of the two variables as between-subjects factors. As an additional test of both hypotheses, the same multivariate general linear model analyses will be performed, this time with the pain experience PE2 scores (pleasantness, intensity, pain, and fear) at post-intervention as dependent variables.
